com.mrcrayfish.device.api.app

Class Layout

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.minecraft.client.gui.Gui
      • com.mrcrayfish.device.api.app.Component
        • com.mrcrayfish.device.api.app.Layout
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    Layout.Context, ScrollableLayout

    public class Layout
extends Component
    The Layout class is the main implementation for displaying components in your application. You can have multiple layouts in your application to switch interfaces during runtime.

    Use Application.setCurrentLayout(Layout) inside of Wrappable.init(net.minecraft.nbt.NBTTagCompound) to set the current layout for your application.

    Check out the example applications to get a better understand of how this works.

    • Constructor Detail

      • Layout

        public Layout()
        Default constructor. Initializes a layout with a width of 200 and a height of 100. Use the alternate constructor to set a custom width and height.

      • Layout

        public Layout(int width,
              int height)

      • Layout

        public Layout(int left,
              int top,
              int width,
              int height)
        Constructor to set a custom width and height. It should be noted that the width must be in the range of 20 to 362 and the height 20 to 164.
        Parameters:
        width -
        height -

      • render

        public void render(com.mrcrayfish.device.core.Laptop laptop,
                   net.minecraft.client.Minecraft mc,
                   int x,
                   int y,
                   int mouseX,
                   int mouseY,
                   boolean windowActive,
                   float partialTicks)
        Renders the background of this layout if a Layout.Background has be set. See setBackground(Background).
        Overrides:
        render in class Component
        Parameters:
        laptop - a Gui instance
        mc - a Minecraft instance
        x - the starting x rendering position (left most)
        y - the starting y rendering position (top most)
        mouseX - the current x position of the mouse
        mouseY - the current y position of the mouse
        windowActive - if the window is active (at front)
        partialTicks - percentage passed in-between two ticks
